column1: Ranong (Thai: ระนอง (Pronunciation)) is a town (thesaban mueang) in southern Thailand
column2: former capital of the Ranong Province and the Mueang Ranong District. The town covers completely the area of the tambon Khao Niwet (เขานิเวศน์). As of 2005
column4: 163. Ranong lies 586 kilometres (364 mi) south-southwest of Bangkok by road.

column1: Ranong is on the estuary of the Pak Chan (or Kraburi) River
column2: opposite Myanmar's Kawthaung (formerly Victoria Point). The Tenasserim Hills rise directly to the east of Ranong
column3: and another small ridge runs along the edge of the estuary to the town's north.

column1: Ranong has a tropical monsoon climate (Köppen climate classification Am). There is little variation in the temperature throughout the year
column2: although the pre-monsoon months (February to April) are somewhat hotter in the day. However
column3: Ranong's position to the west of the Tenasserim Hills means that the monsoon season's rains are greatly amplified
column4: resulting in torrential rains from May until October
column5: and significant rainfall in the transition months of April and November.

column1: Phet Kasem Road (Thailand Route 4) runs through the city. Ranong Airport is about 24 kilometres (15 mi) south of town.
The Port Authority of Thailand operates the Ranong Port
column2: which is Thailand's principal Indian Ocean port. In 2008
column3: the Ranong human-smuggling incident resulted in 54 deaths.
